issueDTO.title: Separate transportation and intersection info in the Mobility category
issueDTO.description: Separate transportation and intersection items in the Mobility category under Manage Callouts' in the main Settings menu
comments: That switch actually controls three callout groups: intersections, transportation, and safety (e.g. steps and other hazards). Do we want to group safety with intersections or with transportation? Arguably the intersections are a type of safety callout, but perhaps the point of separating the intersection callout toggle is to allow everything except intersections to continue being called out.

That's a great point :-) Perhaps we split out all 3 separately? All the other Callout options are quite binary whereas this one currently incorporates 3 different types...so splitting them out will allow a person to fine-tune the information they wish to hear. It will increase the panel and require more scrolling for the page...but I think it's worth doing.

I could also argue that the safety spots callout should remain on unless the user decides to turn all callouts off. In the early days of Microsoft Soundscape, there used to be a toggle switch for the Location Updates callout, but starting around the early 2020's,the Location Updates callout became permanently turned on and cannot directly be configured by the user. My argument to leave safety spots on is so that the user is always aware of anything hazardous while walking around. That way the "Manage Callouts" menu wouldn't be cluttered with too many configurations. If we decide to go ahead with my solution, I also wrote a revision to the help documentation explaining "Note: some callouts essential for safe navigation do not have their own toggle switch and can only be disabled with the "Allow Callouts" button." Anyway, having all three callouts in this section or just Transportation and Intersections will be an improvement, even for sighted users. The term Mobility isn't as intuitive for the average user.
I can look into this
Do we know which files in the backend are connected to the different toggles that we want from the Mobility section?

The code where the single toggle is changing three separate settings is here: https://github.com/soundscape-community/soundscape/blob/6a84924d63fc0a2542abac51d8c823832f0330d7/apps/ios/GuideDogs/Code/Visual%20UI/Controls/Settings/CalloutSettingsCellView.swift#L84-L90

The visual design for the toggle is in a storyboard: https://github.com/soundscape-community/soundscape/blob/6a84924d63fc0a2542abac51d8c823832f0330d7/apps/ios/GuideDogs/Code/Visual%20UI/Views/Settings.storyboard#L270-L317

That's all you should really need to tweak for this feature. You don't need to dive into how those settings are used by the `AutoCalloutGenerator` to filter the announcements.

Just for clarification, I separated Transportation and Intersection into 2 different toggles. Before I make a pull request I want to confirm that we get rid of the Mobility toggle altogether and it just be the 2 new toggles?

Based on your description, it looks like you are using my suggestion of leaving the safety callouts on permanently without a toggle switch. It might be a good idea to look at the advantages and drawbacks of the two suggestions. Would we rather have fewer toggle switches or a more customizable UI? My own suggestion has the safety callouts to not have a toggle switch so that the user is always aware of them in order to stay safe while walking. This may be good with cane or guide dog travel or for those individuals who are less experienced with O&M because a mobility device alone may not catch some safety spots. This solution also produces a less cluttered UI. You could argue in favor of the previous suggestion from Jchudge that having a toggle for safety callouts so the user turns off everything except for intersections may produce a more streamlined listening experience. That solution could be great for very experienced cane travelers who don't need that much guidance from Soundscape's callouts. The drawback is that the list of toggle switches looks a bit too long and overwhelming for beginners. Should we take a vote or something? Thanks.

Mmm, I don't think we should make safety callouts permanently on.  There's a valid use case for the app  for low-vision non-cane users who don't need assistance finding steps and crosswalks but just want to hear road and shop signs they can't read.

I'd suggest making three toggles, for mobility, transportation, and intersections. This shouldn't be much more difficult than two toggles, since the setting is already split into three under the hood.

Thanks, since I don't object to having three separate toggle switches, should the new buttons be labeled "Transportation," "Intersections," and "Safety?" What should we do with the old "Mobility" switch? I assume that the "Mobility" or "Safety" button would be redundant if both buttons are in the UI so I think we can try either of two solutions. If we keep the "Mobility" label, and use the safety callouts for that label, then we should create an accessibility hint like "Info for safe navigation." If you would rather go with "Safety" as the new callout name, the hint for the button could be written as "Info for safe mobility." I can't come up with a good hint description right now, but you should get the gist. After everything is put together, the final list should be ""Allow Callouts," Places & Landmarks," "Mobility" or "Safety," "Transportation," "Intersections," "Distance to the Audio Beacon" and "Repeat Callouts." Maybe the order of callouts can be switched around a bit. Since the old "Mobility" hint said "Intersection and Transportation Info," it may be better to put the "Transportation" button after the "Intersection" button for consistency.

Ah, good point, the three categories should actually be Mobility, Safety, and Intersections. The "Mobility" category encompasses some random stuff that aren't directly related to modes of transportation, like ATMs and NaviLens codes.

Here's a stab at the new hint text:
* Mobility: Practical features like crosswalks and bus stops.
* Safety: Potential hazards like steps and construction areas
* Intersections: Announce street names and their directions

So how I'm understanding what the final list should look like is this: "Allow Callouts," "Places & Landmarks," "Mobility," "Safety," "Intersections," "Distance to Audio Beacon," and "Repeat Callouts." BTW, thanks for the new accessibility hints.

> So how I'm understanding what the final list should look like is this: "Allow Callouts," "Places & Landmarks," "Mobility," "Safety," "Intersections," "Distance to Audio Beacon," and "Repeat Callouts."

Yep, that sounds right to me.

This message is for MBtheOtaku. I saw some of the changes in your "Log Of Changes" pull request, but it's better if you open a PR just for this issue. When you open up a new PR, be sure to put in the localized text for the new callouts and hints into the strings. That way, when it gets merged, I can be able to translate everything to Spanish on Weblate. BTW, I already have the text of Steinbro's hints in Spanish in my notes so I can just copy and paste. Thanks.

issueDTO.title: Change either `createPara()`in `src/backend/lib/db_helpers/case_manager.ts` and/or any callers so that it's more clear what the argument names are
issueDTO.description:
## Description

Currently, for a developer, it's a bit confusing understanding what is being passed to `createPara()` because it has as long list of parameters *and* it's being imported from another file, as noted by @canjalal (see context and PR below).

This could be improved by somehow naming either the parameters and/or arguments so that they're easier to cross-reference. Ideally, a developer could easily discover which argument matches which parameter without having to open up the file that contains `createPara()`.

As a follow-up, whatever is decided and implemented for this particular case could also be adopted as a new best practice across the app and added as documentation etc (this can optionally split out into its own Issue).

Please see the original description below from @katconnors / @canjalal  to understand the problem more and also refer to @canjalal's comment to see a potential solution.

---

## Context below from original PR (click through to see PR and discussion):

Argument renaming in backend/routers for clarity (note that the original comment references case_manager, but naming is also in the para file as well)- see comment below from PR #433:

"This is a lot of arguments, whose values don't look like the names of the parameters. Can we consider changing this function to take keyword arguments, so that it's clear for example that `req.ctx.auth.session.user?.name ?? ""` is being fed as case_manager_name?"

_Originally posted by @canjalal in https://github.com/sfbrigade/compass/pull/433#discussion_r1807002240_

issueDTO.title: RewriteTablePathUtil doesn't work with v3 deletes
issueDTO.description:
### Apache Iceberg version

1.9.2 (latest release)

### Query engine

None

### Please describe the bug 🐞

When running `TestRewriteTablePathsAction` with format-version=3 the tests fail with the below exception

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Content offset is required for DV
	at org.apache.iceberg.relocated.com.google.common.base.Preconditions.checkArgument(Preconditions.java:141)
	at org.apache.iceberg.FileMetadata$Builder.build(FileMetadata.java:271)
	at org.apache.iceberg.RewriteTablePathUtil.writeDeleteFileEntry(RewriteTablePathUtil.java:498)
	at org.apache.iceberg.RewriteTablePathUtil.lambda$rewriteDeleteManifest$5(RewriteTablePathUtil.java:436)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline$3$1.accept(ReferencePipeline.java:197)
	at java.base/java.util.Iterator.forEachRemaining(Iterator.java:133)
	at java.base/java.util.Spliterators$IteratorSpliterator.forEachRemaining(Spliterators.java:1845)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:509)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:499)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReduceOps$ReduceOp.evaluateSequential(ReduceOps.java:921)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(AbstractPipeline.java:234)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.reduce(ReferencePipeline.java:657)
	at org.apache.iceberg.RewriteTablePathUtil.rewriteDeleteManifest(RewriteTablePathUtil.java:444)
	at org.apache.iceberg.spark.actions.RewriteTablePathSparkAction.writeDeleteManifest(RewriteTablePathSparkAction.java:606)
	at org.apache.iceberg.spark.actions.RewriteTablePathSparkAction.lambda$toManifests$f0b4715c$1(RewriteTablePathSparkAction.java:547)
```

This is because https://github.com/apache/iceberg/blob/main/core/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/RewriteTablePathUtil.java#L493-L498 doesn't carry over DVs properly.

We need to carry over `contentOffset` / `contentSizeInBytes` / `referencedDataFile` (most likely in the `copy()` method). Also we need to update `TestRewriteTablePathsAction` to work with format versions 2 and above

### Willingness to contribute

- [ ] I can contribute a fix for this bug independently
- [ ] I would be willing to contribute a fix for this bug with guidance from the Iceberg community
- [ ] I cannot contribute a fix for this bug at this time
comments:
@nastra Hi, I would like to try it out! could I try this on?
I'm a beginner, but I'll do my best!
@capDoYeonLee yes go for it. Nobody expressed interest in working on this so far, so just feel free to open a PR and we'll go from there
@nastra @szehon-ho  I am wondering if it make sense to throw exceptions before 1.10 release until DV is properly supported?
Also FYI @singhpk234 https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/7011/files#r2230609759

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: Version mismatch in manifest files
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

The [input manifest](https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/blob/main/manifests/3.0.0-alpha1/opensearch-3.0.0-alpha1.yml#L5-L6) contains version (3.0.0) and a qualifier (alpha1) as two separate values.

However, the [build manifest](https://ci.opensearch.org/ci/dbc/distribution-build-opensearch/3.0.0-alpha1/10898/linux/x64/tar/builds/opensearch/manifest.yml) (the interim manifest) generated after building all the components as well as the bundle or [distribution manifest](https://ci.opensearch.org/ci/dbc/distribution-build-opensearch/3.0.0-alpha1/10901/linux/x64/tar/dist/opensearch/manifest.yml), generated assembling the components contains a single version key with qualifier already attached `3.0.0-alpha1`

This discrepancy lead to some notable side effects. All the post build and test workflows/ jenkins libraries use version as the key for parsing data from opensearch-metrics cluster. See sample [queries](https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aopensearch-project%2Fopensearch-build-libraries+version%3A+%22%24%7Bthis.version%7D%22&type=code). However, data is indexed using build or dist manifest (in this case version=3.0.0-alpha1).

In order to retrieve the data, the version is retrieved from input manifest which is considered as the source of the truth. Because of this mismatch, it is now trying to run queries with `3.0.0` and returning no data. Example: https://build.ci.opensearch.org/job/integ-test-notification/3496/console

### To reproduce

See the input manifest and compare with dist and build manifest.

### Expected behavior

The version across all the manifests should be same. Either pick `3.0.0` with qualifier as `alpha1` OR pick version: `3.0.0-alpha1`
Accordingly modify the code base to accommodate this changes. 

### Screenshots

If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

### Host / Environment

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

### Relevant log output

```shell

```
comments:
[Triage] @gaiksaya could you add the next steps for us to follow up on this?

Thanks.
@gaiksaya How is this issue at the moment? Does it still have to be solved?

~~@ajleong623 I am already on it and assigned myself.~~

Edit: Just realize I commented on the wrong issue. pending @gaiksaya response.

Thanks.

Hi @ajleong623 @peterzhuamazon ,

Yes, the issue still exists. 
We have workarounds added to separate out the version and qualifier and accordingly use it in the required space (see above linked PRs) but the issue needs to be fixed for uniform versioning across different manifests.
@gaiksaya I looked at the manifests folder, and I noticed that pretty much other versions do not have a qualifier. Would those versions not run into this issue?

> [@gaiksaya](https://github.com/gaiksaya) I looked at the manifests folder, and I noticed that pretty much other versions do not have a qualifier. Would those versions not run into this issue?

No! Qualifier is an optional field. No key = no qualifier. Just the version. Checkout the schema here: https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/blob/main/src/manifests/input_manifest.py#L71

@gaiksaya So, the original problem is that when the data is retrieved, it uses the version with the input manifest. Therefore, we need to make sure the specifier is accounted for when parsing the key for retrieving data? However, with the changes linked above, the specifier is accounted for in the workflows. I do not really understand the issue with uniform versioning across different manifests.

Compare the schemas for [build manifest](https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/blob/main/src/manifests/build_manifest.py#L52), [distribution manifest](https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/blob/main/src/manifests/bundle_manifest.py#L38) and [input manifest ](https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/blob/main/src/manifests/input_manifest.py#L71). 

Only input manifest contains the key `qualifier` and is correctly used. Where as for build and distribution manifest, the qualifier is appended to the version itself. `version: version-qualifier` which is inconsistent with that of input manifest.
It should be uniform across all manifests. Have below keys and values assigned correctly

```
version : 3.0.0
qualifier: beta1
```

@gaiksaya At first glance, it seems like changing the input manifest to have the qualifier appended might be the simpler solution. That way, whenever there is a retrieval of the data, and the version from the input manifest is used, it would be consistent with the build and distribution manifests. But I am skeptical because that seems too simple. I am not sure what the issue with that solution is as I am still a bit unfamiliar with the OpenSearch-build codebase.

The schema for input manifest and the related code base accommodates input manifest qualifier. Would recommend to keep that as it and instead let build and distribution manifest adopt the qualifier key into its schema.

@gaiksaya Ok, I think I get it. So, what I could do is make sure the build and distribution manifest schemas both support the qualifier. When the build and distribution manifests are created, they would also take in the qualifier parameter from the input.

@gaiksaya I linked a pull request with the changes, but it is still a draft. By adding the qualifier value to the manifests, a lot changed in the workflow. How can I test that I did not break anything?

> [@gaiksaya](https://github.com/gaiksaya) I linked a pull request with the changes, but it is still a draft. By adding the qualifier value to the manifests, a lot changed in the workflow. How can I test that I did not break anything?

Thanks for this effort @ajleong623 
You can test using 3.0.0-alpha1 or beta1 version which has a qualifier. Details on how to build: https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/wiki/Building-an-OpenSearch-and-OpenSearch-Dashboards-Distribution#building-from-source

@gaiksaya I tried building from the input, and the contents of the tar folder and logs look accurate. I also looked at the new manifests from the build workflow and the assemble workflow, and the qualifiers are now a separated value. I am looking through all the manifest files, and I noticed that on top of the manifest, there are also the components within the manifests. Did the issue of separating the version also apply to the components within the manifests such as in https://github.com/opensearch-project/opensearch-build/blob/main/src/manifests/build_manifest.py#L140? Another issue is when the workflows try to receive the data from the input manifest, and the version is indexed (without the qualifier), there could be multiple version-qualifier pairs for the input manifest that match the distribution or build manifests at that version. How could I run the sample queries to reproduce the original issue?

Hi @ajleong623 Qualifier should exist on the top `build` level only.

The build.version represents the release version, ex: `3.0.0`.

Then each component with its own version, which can be 3 digit `3.0.0` like OS and OSD core, or 4 digit `3.0.0.0` like any other plugins. We do not need to add a qualifier per component level because that is consistent across the board. Thanks.
@peterzhuamazon understood. In that case, I think the pull request should be ready. Building from input and the assemble workflow now support qualifiers in the build and distribution manifests.

issueDTO.title: Ongoing documentation fixes
issueDTO.description:
There occasionally are "small" fixes for the generated docmentation. These range from "fixing typos" to "fixing broken links" or "fixing type annotations". These usually do not involve rigorous tests, because this _only_ refers to fixes that do _not_ affect the functionality. A corner case is that of TSDoc fixes that may affect the generated typings. These may warrant some scrutiny, but still are not covered by real specs, but maybe only by a few lines in the [`Specs/TypeScript/index.ts` file](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/6e8b5d8fba959dd4df92c1aa4c69c6a62900aa0d/Specs/TypeScript/index.ts).

I'd suggest listing these issues here. Everybody can add comments with things that have to be fixed, and we can try to keep track of the things that have been addressed using GitHub `[ ] Task checkboxes`.

- [x] The `Cesium3DTileset.from...` functions claim to throw a `DeveloperError` when the tileset version is not `0.0` or `1.0`. (E.g. [`fromUrl`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/6e8b5d8fba959dd4df92c1aa4c69c6a62900aa0d/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Cesium3DTileset.js#L1933) and `fromIonAssetId`). 
  **Suggested fix:** This should include `1.1` as a valid version number. 
- [x] These functions are actually not throwing a `DeveloperError`, but a `RuntimeError`, as of [this check](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/6e8b5d8fba959dd4df92c1aa4c69c6a62900aa0d/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Cesium3DTileset.js#L2122). 
  **Suggested fix:** Considering that the developer does not have influence on whether ~"the data is valid", it should probably be a `RuntimeError` (and documented accordingly)
- [x] The `...GeometryUpdater#isDynamic` property documentation contains invalid links. (For example, the [`PolylineGeometryUpdater` documentation](https://cesium.com/learn/cesiumjs/ref-doc/PolylineGeometryUpdater.html#isDynamic), generated from [`PolylineGeometryUpdater`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/9f43e81832fd90a4d3e6b67f6b168b6131bf7ce6/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/PolylineGeometryUpdater.js#L259), but also other updater classes). 
  **Suggested fix:** It should just omit the part that says
  ```
   * If true, all visualization is delegated to the {@link DynamicGeometryUpdater}
   * returned by GeometryUpdater#createDynamicUpdater.
  ```
  This is an implementation detail that is not relevant for the reader of the documentation.
- [x] The [`EntityCollection#add` function](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/9f43e81832fd90a4d3e6b67f6b168b6131bf7ce6/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/EntityCollection.js#L268) claims to throw a `DeveloperError` for duplicate IDs, but actually throws a `RuntimeError`.
  **Suggested fix:** It should be a `DeveloperError`. The developer should make sure that there are no duplicate IDs. (In doubt, the developer can trivially check whether an ID is already present)

- [x] The `orientation` property in the [entity constructor options](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/7ea4b84b681cd17bc61a64921837d4380040ae24/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/Entity.js#L74) is documented to be of type `Property`, but it can also be a `Quaternion`.
  **Suggested fix:** Change the type to `{Property | Quaternion}`. Investigate whether the same applies to other properties there.
comments:
- [ ] There are many places that define a specific type for a certain property (like `Cartesian3`), but they also define a `default` value that may be `undefined`. This is an inconsistency insofar that it's not possible to assign `undefined` there, and the type of the property should have been `Cartesian3 | undefined` to begin with. One example (and a regex for finding others) is mentioned in the issue around https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/issues/11475#issuecomment-1858825468 
  **Suggested fix:** Add `... | undefined` in all these places
  - Some instances of this have been addressed as part of https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/pull/12193 
  - Further instances of this have been addressed in https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/pull/12736 

- [ ] It's not really a "documentation" fix, but ... way not warrant a full-fledged PR: I _think_ that [this `updateStages`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/ba6f5a31ba210527a7e11274285a50aa3001d8ac/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Model/ModelRuntimePrimitive.js#L175) is not used
  **Suggested fix:** Remove it...

> * There are many places that define a specific type for a certain property (like `Cartesian3`), but they also define a `default` value that may be `undefined`. This is an inconsistency insofar that it's not possible to assign `undefined` there, and the type of the property should have been `Cartesian3 | undefined` to begin with. One example (and a regex for finding others) is mentioned in the issue around [Can't unset constrainedAxis in typescript without casting ??#11475 (comment)](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/issues/11475#issuecomment-1858825468)
>   **Suggested fix:** Add `... | undefined` in all these places

Analysing ./pakages/**

```regex
@default\s+(undefined|null)\s*\n([^/]*\n)*.*@type\s+
```

No results, means no `@type` after `@default` in same annotation block.

```regex
@type\s+.*\n([^/]*\n)*.*@default\s+(undefined|null)\s*\n
```

100+ results, means 100+ targets.

```regex
@type\s+.*(undefined|null).*\n([^/]*\n)*.*@default\s+(undefined|null)\s*\n
```

5 results, means 5 correct, including fixed [#11475](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/issues/11475#issuecomment-1858825468), in 100+ targets.

(State of 1.121)

- [ ] The `InterpolationAlgorithm` that is linked, for example, from [`SampledProperty.setInterpolationOptions`](https://cesium.com/learn/cesiumjs/ref-doc/SampledProperty.html#setInterpolationOptions) (but also other places) leads to a 404 right now
  - This was brought up in https://community.cesium.com/t/interpolationalgorithm-page-lost/35086
- [ ] The same applies to `Packable`
- [ ] The `Packable` interface is listed in the ["See..." list of `Matrix4`](https://cesium.com/learn/cesiumjs/ref-doc/Matrix4.html) and others, and should probably be listed in _all_ implementing classes. But it is **not** listed in `Matrix2` and `Matrix3`
- [ ] I think that `positions` in [this line](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/05380a6d7f7869483f63d6a3bbbd89d68ebd1531/Source/Core/GeometryInstance.js#L7) should be `position`**`ed`**
- [ ] The types of the `extension...` objects [here](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/6c2e520420b95bcb6c8eba0f02c76347cee1dd4b/packages/engine/Source/Scene/GltfStructuralMetadataLoader.js#L23) are not `{string}`, but `{object|undefined}`

Not really a "documentation" fix, but ...

- [ ] Rename https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/6c2e520420b95bcb6c8eba0f02c76347cee1dd4b/Apps/Sandcastle/gallery/Globe%20Materials%20%E2%80%93%20Water%20Mask%20Elevation%20Map.html (and the corresponding JPG) to **not** contain that special "???" character!!! (Ever tried to `git add...` such a file at a Windows console?)

Also not a "documentation" fix, but maybe part of a cleanup that does not affect functionality:

- [ ] I'm pretty sure that [`frameState.light`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/e3e98371830a85d653c2f9e1f34f382c84984bce/packages/engine/Source/Scene/FrameState.js#L378) is not used. If it _really_ is not used, it could be removed.

- [ ] The example/snippet that is currently shown at https://cesium.com/learn/ion-sdk/ref-doc/Camera.html works for a _new_ camera. But as soon as this camera is _used_, it generates a 
  > "DeveloperError: normalized result is not a number"

  This is related to the `position` being (0,0,0). I'd go so far and consider this as a _bug_ in the `Camera` itself, but wanted to keep track of this here. 
  Illustration: https://sandcastle.cesium.com/index.html# 
  Edit: When setting `globe:false`, then it bails out with
  > "TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'height')

  Illustration: https://sandcastle.cesium.com/index.html#
  (I'll probably open a broader issue for all this soon...)

- [ ] Not sure what the "callback" and "log messages" part refers to at https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/30559097f7d8836c577c1b6842b3970923316b4e/packages/engine/Source/Scene/GltfPipeline/getComponentReader.js#L135

- [ ] Not really a "documentation fix", but ... that `, Property.equals` part should be replaced by a `Property.equals` call, at
  - https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/1c892c87bd3f6eae234379bcf13344f5d0db6e59/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/CompositeMaterialProperty.js#L118
  -  https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/1c892c87bd3f6eae234379bcf13344f5d0db6e59/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/CompositePositionProperty.js#L144
  -  https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/1c892c87bd3f6eae234379bcf13344f5d0db6e59/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/CompositeProperty.js#L138
  - https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/1c892c87bd3f6eae234379bcf13344f5d0db6e59/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/TimeIntervalCollectionPositionProperty.js#L144
  - https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/1c892c87bd3f6eae234379bcf13344f5d0db6e59/packages/engine/Source/DataSources/TimeIntervalCollectionProperty.js#L126

- [ ] The [`Axis`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/31670c1b4a346353f7dffba98d4e8daade04d030/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Axis.js#L42) class and the associated `..._UP_TO_..._UP` matrices do not appear in the documentation.
- [ ] The one that was brought up in https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/issues/12537 seems uncontroversial for me...

Not actually a documentation fix, but rather a _bug_ fix: 

- [ ] [`TileCoordinatesImageryProvider.minimumLevel`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/53889cbed2a91d38e0fae4b6f2dcf6783632fc92/packages/engine/Source/Scene/TileCoordinatesImageryProvider.js#L109) claims to return a `{number}`, but returns `undefined`...

- [ ] I'm pretty sure that the word "less" in ["Enabling this option will allow for less frustums in the multi-frustum"](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/d84c095c8ffaa585bc74ae2151a36e4835caa8ec/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Scene.js#L1552) should be "fewer" ...

- [X] The documentation says `3x3` where it should say `4x4` at https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/b661763788689a93d16a5704645c82b7cfdc18c0/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Model/UniformType.js#L109 (mentioned in https://community.cesium.com/t/collect-typing-errors-in-api-documentation-and-source-code/40332/2 )

EDIT: Fixed via https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/pull/12656
The PR fixes only the last comment here. Beyond that, this issue is "ongoing", meaning that it will only be closed when the whole documentation is complete and perfect. (I.e. never 🙂 ).

> The PR fixes only the last comment here. Beyond that, this issue is "ongoing"

Thanks @javagl , my mistake, the PR was linked to the issue

- [ ] The `Ellipsoid.cartesianToCartographic` function is said to return `Cartesian`, but can actually return `Cartesian | undefined`: https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/1199e7f5bc1248539b47e5fa818f14ee31c7e2b4/packages/engine/Source/Core/Ellipsoid.js#L496

- [x] For some reason, some of the `@see` values at https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/0ca6a3e60d8cca6a05aa78d33d5ea7e5e3415be1/packages/engine/Source/Scene/ImageryLayer.js#L530 are not linked in the generated documentation

- [ ] Links simply don't work in `@default` tags. For example, https://cesium.com/learn/ion-sdk/ref-doc/ImageryLayer.html#saturation contains `@default {@link ImageryLayer.DEFAULT_SATURATION}`, but the result is not a `@link`.

- [ ] The `featureIdLabel` and `instanceFeatureIdLabel` are both defined to be `string` in the JSDoc at https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/668c2050e19756a0effbd0ddaa613a350dbf30b3/packages/engine/Source/Scene/Cesium3DTileset.js#L2054 (and below that). But they can actually receive a `number` value, which is magically converted into a `string` internally.

- [ ] The [`TilingScheme.prototype.positionToTileXY`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/668c2050e19756a0effbd0ddaa613a350dbf30b3/packages/engine/Source/Core/TilingScheme.js#L130) and the implementations in [`GeographicTilingScheme`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/668c2050e19756a0effbd0ddaa613a350dbf30b3/packages/engine/Source/Core/GeographicTilingScheme.js#L204) and [`WebMercatorTilingScheme`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/668c2050e19756a0effbd0ddaa613a350dbf30b3/packages/engine/Source/Core/WebMercatorTilingScheme.js#L245) boldly claim to return a `Cartesian2`, but they can return `undefined` as well.

- [ ] Down to the roots: The [`Rectangle`](https://github.com/CesiumGS/cesium/blob/0ca6a3e60d8cca6a05aa78d33d5ea7e5e3415be1/packages/engine/Source/Core/Rectangle.js#L16) class claims that its coordinates are in radians. And it claims that they are in a certain range. And it claims that `west` is the "westernmost" longitude. None of that is necessarily true. The `TilingScheme.rectangleToNativeRectangle` returns a `Rectangle` that uses degrees, for example. Methods that _receive_ a `Rectangle` usually don't say what unit they expect or which range they accept, or how they handle out-of-range cases. Methods that _return_ a `Rectangle` usually don't say what unit or range they provide. The 'east', 'south', 'west', and 'north' properties don't have a real "meaning" at this point.

Edit after 9 hours of debugging: This does not only affect the _documentation_. Implementations, like that of the `width` getter, _assume_ that the statements from the documentation are true. But they aren't. The results of the computations of these functions are often plainly _wrong_.

issueDTO.title: [p5.strands] Increasing strands' presence in the reference
issueDTO.description:
### Increasing access

p5.strands is currently undocumented, with only tutorials as learning resources

### Most appropriate sub-area of p5.js?

- [ ] Accessibility
- [ ] Color
- [ ] Core/Environment/Rendering
- [ ] Data
- [ ] DOM
- [ ] Events
- [ ] Image
- [ ] IO
- [ ] Math
- [ ] Typography
- [ ] Utilities
- [x] WebGL
- [ ] Build process
- [ ] Unit testing
- [ ] Internationalization
- [ ] Friendly errors
- [x] Other (specify if possible)

### Feature enhancement details

p5.strands requires more thorough documentation so that it's more discoverable and understandable. The idea is to add p5.strands examples to the reference in places which currently have GLSL examples (keeping them side by side to show both work). 

For example:
- [p5.Shader.modify](https://beta.p5js.org/reference/p5.shader/modify/)
- [setUniform](https://beta.p5js.org/reference/p5.shader/setuniform/)
- [filter](https://beta.p5js.org/reference/p5/filter/)

Additional examples could be added to _any_ WebGL functions, including primitive shapes like [box](https://beta.p5js.org/reference/p5/box/).

issueDTO.title: Consider `bowler test` command to run BowlerTestCases
issueDTO.description: This could provide a nice entry point for discovering and/or executing BowlerTestCases contained within codemod files.
comments: can you explain me this issue in detail

## Proposal: `bowler test` Command to Run BowlerTestCases

**Summary:**  
Introduce a `bowler test` command to the Bowler CLI for discovering and running `BowlerTestCase` classes defined within codemod files.

---

### Motivation

- Currently, there???s no easy way to automatically discover and execute tests for codemods.
- A built-in test runner would help contributors validate codemods, improve reliability, and encourage good testing practices.

---

### Proposed Functionality

- `bowler test` should:
  - Recursively discover all Python files containing `BowlerTestCase` subclasses within the current directory or a specified path.
  - Run all discovered test cases, leveraging Python???s built-in `unittest` framework.
  - Support common options such as:
    - `--path` or positional arguments to specify where to search for tests
    - `-v`/`--verbose` for detailed output
    - Filtering tests by name or file
  - Return a nonzero exit code if any tests fail.

---

### Example Usage

```sh
# Run all tests in the current directory
bowler test

# Run tests in a specific folder
bowler test codemods/my_mods/

# Verbose output
bowler test -v
```

---

### Implementation Sketch

- Use Python???s `unittest` discovery to find and run all `BowlerTestCase` subclasses.
- Add a new CLI subcommand to Bowler (`test`).
- Print summary output (tests run, passes, failures).

---

**Feedback Requested:**
- Are there additional features or options that would be useful?
- Should the command support integration with other test runners (like pytest)?
- Any concerns with using `unittest` as the default?

---

If this sounds good, I can start working on a prototype and open a pull request. Let me know your thoughts!
Hi! As a first time contributor, I would love to implement this request. Please let me know about the preferences or constraints of this assignment.

issueDTO.title: 🙏 Help wanted: Deprecate old plugin backends
issueDTO.description:
**TL;DR** make sure that `createRouter` and other exports are marked as deprecated. For the majority of packages there should only be one default export of the backend plugin itself. The `@backstage/backend-common` package is deprecated so usages of that package should also be avoided.

Backstage???s [new backend system](https://backstage.io/docs/backend-system/) is ready for general use; we are now asking for a full transition over to the new backend system, which involves [stop supporting the old system](https://backstage.io/docs/backend-system/building-plugins-and-modules/migrating/#remove-support-for-the-old-backend-system). By old system we mean having exports of `createRouter` and related types. There should only need to be one export like [this](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/5d92499845e60e154b80481a679bfa3ec12f0dfb/plugins/notifications-backend/src/index.ts#L16) in the backend plugin???s `index.ts` file.

## How do I help?

Run `yarn backstage-repo-tools lint legacy-backend-exports` in the repository to get a full report of packages that require action.

### Phase 1

#### Ensure that plugins contain a default export

Ensure that there is a default export of the backend plugin in `index.ts`, see [this example](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/5d92499845e60e154b80481a679bfa3ec12f0dfb/plugins/notifications-backend/src/index.ts#L16).

If the plugin previously had a default export in `plugins/<plugin-id>/src/alpha.ts`, make sure that that export is deprecated and that the default export is moved to the non-alpha `index.ts` instead.

#### Deprecate `createRouter`, `RouterOptions` and similar types.

Here???s an [example](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/26078) of a plugin???s `createRouter` being deprecated.

```diff
/**
+ * @deprecated Please migrate to the new backend system as this will be removed in the future.
 * @public
 * */
export async function createRouter(
  options: RouterOptions,
): Promise<express.Router> {
```

### Phase 2

#### Remove deprecated exports

Ensure that deprecations have been out for at one mainline release before proceeding with removal of all deprecated exports. Removing exports from one release to another is not recommended 

The complete migration story for a backend plugin (including deprecation) is also mentioned in our [docs](https://backstage.io/docs/backend-system/building-plugins-and-modules/migrating#remove-support-for-the-old-backend-system).

If you take on migrating a backend plugin, feel free to add a comment in this issue to avoid duplicate work.

We plan to have all `createRouter` exports and `@backstage/backend-common` usages removed by the end of this year. Your help would be much appreciated!

Hope to gain some eyeballs please: In  `plugins/kubernetes-backend`, there seems to be a few side-effect imports of `@backstage/backend-common`, e.g. this one: 
https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/ab209e4964ee90de5899e8269f6255243d51e811/plugins/kubernetes-backend/src/cluster-locator/CatalogClusterLocator.test.ts#L17

I guess that some time ago, `@backstage/backend-common` had side effects, but I'm not sure if we can proceed to remove it now. As I don't have familiarity on how the side effect was used, hope to get some context from us 🙏

Together with my #30352, that would remove usage in the biggest backend plugins that users will import 🎉

I'm invested and can help to create the MR for `kubernetes-backend` too. Like #28969, we are using Trivy scan and there's this nagging vulnerability that will go away once we no longer depends on `@backstage/backend-common`.
Can I try working on this issue ?

> Can I try working on this issue ?

@Ayushmore1214 oooh awesome! 🎉 I would be interested to see this moves 🙏

As @Rugvip [says](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/issues/26353#issuecomment-2373497777):
> This is completely open to contributions 🙏
Sorry for inconvenience @Teo-ShaoWei , I will be busy for next 5-7 days , If someone else likes to work on this issue till then plz assign them Thank you !

I had a look at the code yesterday. Is there somewhere more information out there how to do the migration for:

* createLegacyAuthAdapters - Migrate to use the new backend system and auth services instead.
* loggerToWinstonLogger - Migrate to use the new LoggerService instead.

the doc [1] doesn't go into details on how to do that.

[1] https://backstage.io/docs/backend-system/building-backends/migrating/#removing-backstagebackend-common

Is [1] the one for auth?

[1] https://backstage.io/docs/tutorials/auth-service-migration/#making-the-new-auth-services-available-in-createrouter

> Is [1] the one for auth?
>
> [1] https://backstage.io/docs/tutorials/auth-service-migration/#making-the-new-auth-services-available-in-createrouter

@azen1k5 wooohooo good find! I was confused for a while looking at it because it seems to do nothing, except make the optional `HttpAuthService` compulsory. Actually I didn't understand it wrongly, this is indeed the state after the old backend has been torn down, e.g. inside the doc you provided:
> In order to make the new auth services available to the plugin implementation in a backwards compatible way, we use the `createLegacyAuthAdapters` helper from `@backstage/backend-common`. This helper accepts both the old and new auth services, and returns implementations for the new ones. If provided with implementations for the new services it will pass them through directly, which is what we want for the new backend system.

In that case, the right thing to do is probably to chase the type upwards and make sure we always have:
```ts
httpAuth: HttpAuthService
```
instead of leaving it optional like:
```ts
httpAuth?: HttpAuthService
```
Currently that's not true and we shouldn't just blindly type assert with:
```ts
httpAuth as HttpAuthService
```
which should cause issues down the road... ...
@Teo-ShaoWei thanks for the nice explanation. I'll give it a try

Hi! Just wanted to follow up here that the only remaining Plugin that still supports the legacy backend is the Kubernetes plugin. Phase 1 was completed for this plugin but we've hit roadblocks with Phase 2:

1. My initial attempt where I hit issues with the logger: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29013
2. Freben's attempt where he resolved the logger issue but hit other items: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015

I think before we go much further we should log a dedicated issue for this so we can get to an agreed upon path forward.

We need to decided on what was mentioned here as this is the current blocker: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015#issuecomment-2753556148

Thanks for the perspective @awanlin 🙏

The removal of `loggerToWinstonLogger` was indeed tricky. I for sure tried what you did as a firsthand approach haha 😂 I think @drodil realized too when he worked on #24224, thus the added comment to:
```ts
// TODO: Add 'log' to LoggerService
```

Could you take a look at #30647 and see if that resolves the issue?

EDIT: Oooh you looked at it already by the time I finished the message! 💪

@azen1k5 have you started working on it? If yes, this is yours since you reserved it first 👍 I can contribute to review of that 💪

If you haven't started yet, then if you don't mind, I can PR what I have... This issue is an itch for me and since it's weekend I thought to try and scratch it just to feel how deep a problem it is... as I scratched it I managed to get to the end of removing `@backstage/backend-common`... hahahah 🤦
However I wasn't able to make much headway for removing legacy backend support for the Kubernetes plugin... I'm with @awanlin that we should log a dedicated issue for that and agree on a plan 👍

HI @Teo-ShaoWei, did you read my message? 

> I think before we go much further we should log a dedicated issue for this so we can get to an agreed upon path forward.
> 
> We need to decided on what was mentioned here as this is the current blocker: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015#issuecomment-2753556148
Seems that you did but not in detail. This isn't simply removing the legacy backend, please read the linked comment: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015#issuecomment-2753556148

Ah I did, apologies 🙇 I think you are concerned with the state of `kubernetes-backend` as a whole, is that right? I tried to look at the messages and the state of the plugin, it's indeed non-trivial.

However the removal of `@backstage/backend-common` can be done separately it seems. As in I managed to remove it while having the tests in the package pass, and `yarn tsc` being ok...

I might not understand enough of the details for sure, so it's my bad if I went off-tangent 😂

If we simply wanted to remove `@backstage/backend-common` then we would have just merged https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015 but as mentioned in the comment I've linked to a few times now https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015#issuecomment-2753556148 there's more to it than that.

Ah! Yes my bad, I didn't give the code a good read. Most of what I have is indeed in #29015 already. Got too excited to chew at the problem haha.

Not sure whether I'm misunderstood though as I'm trying to approach the issue iteratively. To me, it feels like we are crossing a big gap in one jump. Would it have been easier if we take a step closer to the cliff first before the leap to the other side?

Let me submit my PR and we look at it? If it's accepted, we can reduce the problem and at least can address #28969. Some of us are willing to slowly work on this, but our organization's Trivy can't. I'll understand if we decided to reject the PR in the end.

Please, slow down and stop, you're rushing off an not clearly understanding things. If we wanted to moved forward with that PR - created by the Core Maintainers - then again we would have merged the PR I referenced. I'll copy the comment I've referenced a few times as it seems you aren't reading it:

> So I don't think that this is going to work for some use cases.
> 
> I think that it's wise for us to convert some of the extension points into serviceRefs instead, which then give us the ability to get access to the default implementations of some of the dependencies without having to export a load of things from the plugin as right now it's impossible to create a ClusterLocator outside of the plugin without copying a load of code.
> 
> internally we have a requirement that the ServiceLocator needs access to the the ClusterSupplier which I think is pretty standard, but there's no way to create your own ServiceLocator without having access to the implementation of the ClusterSupplier but with extension points this is only possible if you create your own ClusterSupplier in the same scope.
> 
> Moving these to ServiceRefs would mean that you could depend on the default implementation of the ClusterSupplier when overriding the ServiceLocator with your own.

You're changes don't address this and lead to problems for adopters. The above needs to be addressed first.

I appreciate that you want to work on this but it needs to be done correctly and in a thought out way. Any security issues with `@backstage/backend-common` can be resolved with `resolutions` this is what the vast majority of the Community has done as they wait for this work.

Frankly I could be wrong as I'm really new to this piece of code, so just some quick intuition from me.

To me #29015 is a big change, and can be abstractly separated into three parts (A + B + C).

A = changes that doesn't affect logic at all, e.g. refactorings like removal of `@backstage/backend-common`.
B = changes in API that are small and users can fix easily, e.g. removal of the `DiscoveryService`.
C = changes in logic that result in change of existing workflow, e.g. removal of `KubernetesBuilder` and all the helper functions within, so users would need to use what the new backend offers.

I would believe that https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/29015#issuecomment-2753556148 is about the concern that we are not ready to make the change C, because users can't rework their existing workflow.

We are talking across each other this whole time because I guess this is what's on our mind:
@awanlin: "We didn't accept change A + B + C last time. Did you realized that the problem is this big and you haven't address the issue yet?"
@Teo-ShaoWei: "I've derived A + B. Ah yes I think we can't solve C yet... Since the existing blocker is due to C, let's commit A + B first since users will be ok. We can then isolate and solve C."

Did I understand the issue incorrectly?

Sorry if I come off as confrontational. I really appreciate the good work of the core maintainers & the Spotify folks. Backstage is some awesome stuff!

And it's because of that, my organization want to give it a serious try, so I would also hope to do what I technically can to maximize our mutual benefits. I'm currently still inclined to believe that #30653 is such an improvement for us, but I'll be glad if I can be proven wrong. With that, I hope that the PR can get a well-thought review 🙏

No worries @Teo-ShaoWei, the issue is trying to move before having an agreed upon course of action. Sometimes going slow can be fast in the end. I agree with the incremental approach, this is why I approved the Logger PR and worked to get the Kubernetes Plugin owner to approve as well. But what remains is a bit overlapping and I would prefer we get confirmation before taking further steps.

Some additional background, it's the summer time so many people from the project are away so getting this fully reviewed and merged will take time and likely won't make the next month release which is August 19th. So getting this right from the start will help make sure it moves forward with less blocking points.

@Teo-ShaoWei all good take it. I just started and reading up on the code since it's the first time for me seeing backstage from the inside. Happy to have a look at your PR to understand the ins and outs :-)

repository.description: Backstage is an open framework for building developer portals
repository.name: backstage

summary.main: The main goal is to deprecate old plugin backends and remove deprecated exports to transition to the new backend system. This requires careful planning and collaboration to ensure a smooth migration process.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirements for migrating plugins to the new backend system include deprecating old plugin backends, removing deprecated exports, and handling side effects. The community needs to work together to resolve these complexities and ensure a smooth transition.
summary.attemptedFixes: Several attempts have been made to migrate plugins to the new backend system, but some have hit roadblocks. For example, the Kubernetes plugin has issues with the logger and needs further work. The removal of `@backstage/backend-common` has also been attempted, but it's not a straightforward process.
summary.otherNotes: There are several plugins that still support the legacy backend system and need to be migrated to the new backend system. The main goal is to deprecate old plugin backends and remove deprecated exports. There are some blockers and complexities that need to be addressed, such as removing `@backstage/backend-common` package usages and handling side effects. The community is working together to resolve these issues and move forward with the migration.

issueDTO.title: Seek back can cause crash
issueDTO.description: **Environment information** * Operating System: Linux * Cutter version: * Obtained from: - [x] Built from source - [ ] Downloaded release from Cutter website or GitHub - [ ] Distribution repository * File format: **Describe the bug** **To Reproduce** Not sure about exact steps but it happened, when I was testing one of undo seek shortcuts. From the debugger out seems like it might be sufficient to got to the start of history and then trying to go back again. The bug isn't 100% reliable. Maybe there are some other factors involved. **Expected behavior** No crash, no out of bounds array access. **Screenshots** **Additional context**

repository.description: Free and Open Source Reverse Engineering Platform powered by rizin
repository.name: cutter

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve a crash caused by seeking back, which happens when trying to undo past the start of the seek history.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The bug isn't 100% reliable, and there might be other factors involved.
summary.attemptedFixes: The proposed fix is to add a check before using topOffsetHistoryPos as an index, to confirm it's not less than zero and not past the end of the array. A snippet showing the check is provided.
summary.otherNotes: The issue seems to be caused by out-of-bounds array access when trying to undo past the start of the seek history. The variable tracking the current position in the seek history (topOffsetHistoryPos) gets set to -1 when going past the beginning, but the code still tries to use that value as an index for the history array.

issueDTO.title: LO/OO bibliography error when using citations with non-Latin charcters
issueDTO.description:
### JabRef version

6.0-alpha2

### Operating system

Windows

### Details on version and operating system

Windows 11

### Checked with the latest development build (copy version output from About dialog)

- [x] I made a backup of my libraries before testing the latest development version.
- [x] I have tested the latest development version and the problem persists

### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

1. Start JabRef
2. Start a LibreOffice Writer document instance
3. Connect to the document instance from JabRef's OO/LO panel
4. Open a new library
5. Add the following entries to your library:
```bibtex
@Article{????2025,
  author = {????},
  title  = {You},
  year   = {2025},
}

@Article{??2025,
  author = {??},
  title  = {I},
  year   = {2025},
}
```
6. Select a CSL style from the "Select Style" dialog of the OO/LO panel
7. Cite any of the above entries
8. Click the "Make/Sync" bibliography button from the OO/LO panel (not needed if `OO Panel->Settings->Automatically sync bibliography` is enabled)

You will observe the following exception (see appendix) along with the error dialog:
```plain
No cited entries found in the document.
```
And log:
```plain
2025-06-10 22:32:55 [JavaFX Application Thread] org.jabref.logic.openoffice.ReferenceMark.parse()
WARN: CSLReferenceMark: name=JABREF_????2025 CID_1 e2b1z2jv does not match pattern. Assuming random values
```

### Cause
Non-Latin characters are not recognized valid in the "reference marks" format used for LO/OO in JabRef

### Hints to solve
Adapt the regex in:
https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/blob/1ba35d20dbdd0b4aac33e1e594269d76302791b0/jablib/src/main/java/org/jabref/logic/openoffice/ReferenceMark.java#L18-L19

### Pre-requisite context for people not familiar with this aspect of JabRef:
**OO/LO integration:** https://docs.jabref.org/cite/openofficeintegration
**CSL styles - citing and generating bibliographies:** https://blog.jabref.org/2024/08/26/GSoC-CSL/
**"Reference marks" in LibreOffice:** https://devdocs.jabref.org/code-howtos/openoffice/overview.html (may be slightly outdated but conceptually valid).

### Test for completion:
Screen recording of bibliography being successfully generated in the document from the entries mentioned.

### Appendix

...

In case you encounter failing tests during development, please check our [developer FAQs](https://devdocs.jabref.org/code-howtos/faq.html)!

Having any questions or issues? Feel free to ask here on GitHub. Need help setting up your local workspace? Join the conversation on [JabRef's Gitter chat](https://gitter.im/JabRef/jabref). And don't hesitate to open a (draft) pull request early on to show the direction it is heading towards. This way, you will receive valuable feedback.

Happy coding! 🚀

I was going through the SDAG version of computeKnownBits and computeSignBits to see what was missing from GISel. Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor is working on this issue. If someone is assigned to the issue or claimed to be working on it, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. Leave a comment indicating that you are working on the issue, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

@llvm/issue-subscribers-good-first-issue

repository.name: llvm-project

summary.main: Port nodes from SDAG to GISel for computeKnownBits and computeNumSignBits, specifically for nodes that are missing in GISel.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires porting nodes from SDAG to GISel, specifically for computeKnownBits and computeNumSignBits. The nodes need to be ported over and tested to ensure they are working correctly.
summary.attemptedFixes: Some nodes have already been ported over, as indicated by the [Done] labels in the tables. The issue also mentions that some nodes are not relevant to GISel, such as MERGE_VALUES and SCALAR_TO_VECTOR.
summary.otherNotes: This issue is a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. It requires porting nodes from SDAG to GISel, specifically for computeKnownBits and computeNumSignBits. The issue provides a list of nodes that SDAG tries to handle and their current status in GISel. Some nodes have no equivalent in GISel and will need to be ported over. The issue also provides examples of what kind of thing needs to be added and how tests can be written.

issueDTO.title: Allow for a `firstboot.sh` hook script
issueDTO.description: Support our customer with a bit more comfort and add a `firstboot.sh` hook script. If such a script exists kiwi will take the information and turn it into a `oneshot` systemd unit that gets activated and called on first boot
comments:
Good community statement regarding this idea

> Again. I think it's a bad idea to enforce the firstboot actions when there are variations even within distributions.

- systemd
- cloud-init
- ignition
- ... maybe more
From a conversation on the Fedora channel we agree on using cloud-init to be a good choice as it is widely adopted and as a framework expected to be distribution agnostic

IMO a systemd unit with `ConditionFirstBoot=yes` is the best option by far, with cloud-init being the worst by far (way too fat with its dependencies, very slow and known to cause severe issues because it's fairly invasive on its own already)
We cannot (solely) use systemd because we cannot assume its existence in kiwi itself. We _can_ assume cloud-init is available, but we cannot assume any other option.

> We can assume cloud-init is available

Available maybe, but not used. Pulling in cloud-init just to run some firstboot.sh script is a really bad idea. If it's already part of the image it's probably fine, but not in other cases.

> We cannot (solely) use systemd because we cannot assume its existence in kiwi itself. We _can_ assume cloud-init is available, but we cannot assume any other option.

Since kiwi converts the script to a systemd one shoot service: we know that systemd will be available, and we know cloud-init will **not** be available in most cases.
We do? I don't recall us having built-in functionality for this.
Me neither - that's what this issue is for AFAIU?

@thkukuk 
> Since kiwi converts the script to a systemd one shoot service:

No such functionality exists in kiwi today. That's why we are discussing it. We recently added a new `<containers>` section which imports locally embedded container archives to the local container registry via a systemd oneshot service. But this functionality is
exclusively connected to the container import feature (see #2663 ) The produced unit file also only has the task to import container archives into the local registry and not more. The feature we are discussing here is an arbitrary firstboot code that gets executed by *some* system on first boot. What system that should be is basically subject to the conversation

There's nothing stopping someone from dropping a first-boot script into the filesystem with Kiwi's existing functionality. This seems like it would complicate the configuration syntax for very little practical gain.

repository.description: KIWI - Appliance Builder Next Generation
repository.name: kiwi

summary.main: The main goal is to add support for a firstboot.sh hook script, which will be executed on first boot, possibly using cloud-init or systemd.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The script should be converted to a systemd one-shot service, and the system used to execute the script on first boot should be determined.
summary.attemptedFixes: There are no specific fixes mentioned in the issue, but the discussion revolves around the feasibility of using cloud-init and systemd for executing the firstboot script.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about adding a firstboot.sh hook script, which will be converted to a systemd one-shot service. However, there are concerns about using cloud-init, as it's not widely available and can cause issues. The discussion is ongoing about which system to use for executing the script on first boot.

issueDTO.title: BUG: Dangerous-Workflow doesn't trigger on `toJSON(github.event)`
issueDTO.description:
**Describe the bug**
The Dangerous-Workflow check currently only triggers when attacker-controlled data is explicitly declared in the workflow.

https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/130a31f/checks/raw/dangerous_workflow.go#L31-L57

However, if the `github.event` object is converted to a JSON object (i.e. for logging) in a `run:` command on a workflow triggered by an external contribution, its contents will contain attacker-controlled data (i.e. the issue/PR title) which can be used for code injection in the workflow.

For example:

```yml
on:
  pull_request_target:

jobs:
  get-pwned:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Log event and get pwned
        run: echo '${{ toJSON(github.event) }}' | jq
```

**Expected behavior**
Dangerous-Workflow should detect this as a dangerous pattern.
comments: Hello @pnacht and @spencerschrock, We were wondering if this would be a good first issue to work on. To replicate the bug my team made a [test case repo](https://github.com/kailealee/contains-dangerous-workflow) and added the example workflow that was presented by @pnacht. We then ran the Scorecard in our Codespace to see if it would trigger the Dangerous-Workflow, and we got the same result as shown in our screenshot: My team includes @purpleskates123, @jakbrownbytes, @dcaine125, @smrghsh and @devon3583.
Hello , right after we commented on the issue, we realized that someone started working on it and submitted a PR. We reviewed and commented on the PR #4717.

repository.description: OpenSSF Scorecard - Security health metrics for Open Source
repository.name: scorecard

Empowers users to optimize resumes for real-world job portals.

issueDTO.title: Pain with failed pre-commit hooks (Feature Request)
issueDTO.description:
**Imagine a situation** where you have written a good commit message and done the same for its description by adding 3 more lines. Then, after filling out all the required fields, a pre-commit hook is triggered. Unfortunately, one of the style tests fails, and all your efforts to write a meaningful commit message are lost. 

My suggestion is that, if a solution doesn't already exist, we could add something like a text saving feature to the cache, so that you can tap up or down on the keyboard to restore the last text you wrote in the title and description fields.

issueDTO.title: CALM validate outputs incorrect line/character numbers
issueDTO.description:
## Bug Report

### Steps to Reproduce:
Run calm validate on a file with errors or warnings

Look at line numbers in report - they are not correct. This is because the input file is repeatedly converted to and from JSON objects, meaning line number info is discarded.

### Proposed fix
Every warning/error has a JSONPath reference associated with it. 
It may be simpler to simply find that JSONPath in the file and report the line/char number from there.

Failing that, we need to properly propagate the whitespace through the document as we validate it.
comments:
Suggestion for a library: https://github.com/epoberezkin/json-source-map
This builds a source map that maps jsonpaths > line/char nums

I've used Claude Code to help me generate a fix for this ticket and get familiar with the process. I will provide a new PR soon. 
I also need to look at signing a CLA as an individual (https://community.finos.org/docs/governance/software-projects/easycla/)

The problem here is that the pattern and architecture files are converted from string to object and. back to string before validation.

The conversion from object to string is not done with pretty printing, so the Spectral validations are performed on a single line string.

Even if the conversion was pretty printed, the line/char numbers would not correlate to the input file, leading to user confusion.

The solution would need to ensure the original string representation is maintained - assuming it always comes from a string. I suspect there are multiple input routes, some of which are string from file, some are an object over the wire.

repository.description: "Architecture as Code" (AasC) aims to devise and manage software architecture via a machine readable and version-controlled codebase, fostering a robust understanding, efficient development, and seamless maintenance of complex software architectures
repository.name: architecture-as-code

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve the incorrect line and character numbers reported by CALM validate when running on a file with errors or warnings.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The validation requirement is to ensure the original string representation is maintained, assuming it always comes from a string. This is because there are multiple input routes, some of which are string from file, some are an object over the wire.
summary.attemptedFixes: A fix was attempted using Claude Code and a library suggestion was made: https://github.com/epoberezkin/json-source-map. The author also mentioned that they will provide a new PR soon.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to CALM validate reporting incorrect line and character numbers. The problem is caused by repeatedly converting the input file to and from JSON objects, which discards line number information. A suggested fix is to find the JSONPath reference associated with each warning/error and report the line/char number from there. Alternatively, the whitespace should be properly propagated through the document during validation.

issueDTO.title: Remove deprecated `preserveUnknownFields` field from CRDs
issueDTO.description:
**What would you like to be added**:

As of [Kubernetes 1.22, `spec.preserveUnknownFields`  has been removed](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/deprecation-guide/#customresourcedefinition-v122) and replaced by `x-kubernetes-preserve-unknown-fields: true`, which is already being used in the VPC CNI CRDs.

Given Kubernetes versions before 1.22 have been EOL for several years, I'm proposing that `spec.preserveUnknownFields` is completely removed from the CRDs in this repo.

**Why is this needed**:

The latest release of ArgoCD has [removed ignoring `preserveUnknownFields` by default](https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/latest/operator-manual/upgrading/2.14-3.0/#removing-default-ignores-of-preserveunknownfields-for-crd), causing resources to fall of sync constantly when deploying the VPC CNI chart via ArgoCD. There are workarounds to re-ignore this field but I think it should be removed here too for the reasoning above.
comments: Hey @finlaysawyer , thanks for bringing this up to the team. We will take a look at this. If you would like to, feel free to create a PR as well.

issueDTO.title: Request feature to load balance across multiple Kafka topics
issueDTO.description:
We have a very large deployment and we hit limits on what a single Kafka topic can support. Limitation is due to the number of nodes partitions, number of disks on nodes number threads etc... We find keeping our topics to a manageable size we have less issues. Can you add a feature to Kafka output to load balance across multiple topics? 

I know we can set the policy to point to different paths with different backends in the endpoints but that defeats the autoscaling load balancing that this service can support. 

Maybe a number_of_topics where _# could be appended to topic names like  topic_1, topic_2 etc???
base_topic_name = "topic_base_name"
number_of_topics = 3
Results in incoming messages being published to topics topic_base_name_1, topic_base_name_2, topic_base_name_3

Or topics be made a list...
topics = "topic_base_name_1, topic_base_name_2, topic_base_name_3"
comments:
Hi!

I'm quite surprised that you reached the limits of Kafka by collecting events with OpenWEC. Out of curiosity, could you share an estimate of how many machines you are collecting events from and what your traffic is like (e.g. number of events, byte rate)?

I don't understand how increasing the number of topics would improve performance (except if you have only one partition per topic). Could you share a documentation or an article stating about that? 

I would rather suggest to:
- increase the number of partitions in your topic
- increase the number of nodes in the Kafka cluster (at least one partition per node)
- improve the storage technology used to store Kafka partitions (SSD)
- tweak producer(s) configuration (batch size for example)
- tweak consumer(s) configuration
- tweak topic configuration (e.g. partition size, partition retention time)

Hi! I am from Brian's team. We have 100k+ workstations and ~5500 servers that we going to collect from. 

If there is a substantially huge volume on one single topic, it fills up the disk unevenly on a Kafka cluster.  This makes the team go into maintenance mode, rebalancing partitions which is tedious, sometimes error prone and time consuming all while hoping we don't miss realtime logs. So we have retention time and retention bytes applied to the partition. This keeps the busy work from us. But this means we need to monitor the volume and split the topic into more as they reach a certain level otherwise retention time criteria is not met.
Our consumers scaling logic is shared across all log sources including wef. They all(300+) scale for up to 24 partitions so we don't have to handle scaling on case by case basis.

So we keep it fixed to 24 and make new topics if we reach more volume(message/sec) or more size(bytes/sec) than a number.

Long story short, one could use 100s of partitions in Kafka on single topic if we are building a new system just to process windows events but after having tuned all other bits and pieces of the system, an ability to load balance across topics would make our life easier.

Forwarders like winlogbeats, logstash, etc. provide some sort of scripting and variable name for topic etc.. that we use to split volume to multiple topics. Does openwec has similar capability? Hoping we could work around.

Thanks for the explanations! I'm very interested in knowing how you deployed OpenWEC and how it behaves with that type of charge. 

> Does openwec has similar capability?

We don't have that feature yet.

As you mentioned, if the Kafka driver configuration contains multiple topics, the expected behavior is for the received events to be distributed fairly among the configured topics. This behavior does not seem to be implemented in the Kafka producer library itself, so we need to implement it ourselves. However, the Kafka producer library can send each message (e.g., a Windows event) to a different topic.

Currently, the Kafka driver is stateless. This means that we cannot use a "global" round-robin index to fairly rotate between topics without making significant changes to the Kafka driver logic and possibly impacting performance. The Kafka driver, however, receives a batch of events to send in a single "write" call (https://github.com/cea-sec/openwec/blob/main/server/src/drivers/kafka.rs#L84). Therefore, I think we can use a "local" round-robin index to achieve relative fairness. The idea is to start at a random position in the topics array and iterate through the array for each event.

I prefer your second proposal of adding a "topics" parameter to the Kafka driver configuration that contains a pre-made topics list. This approach seems much easier to understand and less likely to be used incorrectly. Additionally, if both "topics" and "topic" are present, an error should be raised.

Does this approach feel reasonable to you? It does not seem difficult to implement. Would you be interested in implementing it?

repository.description: An implementation of a Windows Event Collector server running on GNU/Linux.
repository.name: openwec

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to request a feature to load balance across multiple Kafka topics to handle large deployments and avoid hitting limits on a single Kafka topic.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The requirement is to add a feature to Kafka output to load balance across multiple topics. The author suggests increasing the number of partitions in the topic, increasing the number of nodes in the Kafka cluster, improving storage technology, tweaking producer and consumer configurations, and tweaking topic configuration.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests implementing a 'topics' parameter in the Kafka driver configuration that contains a pre-made topics list. This approach seems easier to understand and less likely to be used incorrectly.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to Kafka topic limits and the need for load balancing across multiple topics. The current Kafka producer library does not have this feature implemented, but the author suggests a possible solution by using a 'local' round-robin index to fairly distribute events among topics.
